For the Fulbright grantees in these two categories, the orientation was optional; they
had eleoted to oome to Perugia. In some instances they had wished to sharpen their usage of
the Italian language in the practical courses at the University for Foreigners. Others had
wished to "broaden their knowledge of the whole range of Italian life end history — in short,
to get intellectually acclimated "before starting the year’s work.
After the month at Perugia, Miss Terese Anastasia, supervisor of physical therapy at
Bellevue hospital in Hew York City, would lecture at the University of Rome medical school.
Professor Shepard Clough of the Columbia university history faculty would teach American
economic history at the University of Turin. David leeks, professor of agricultural economic!
at the University of California, would lecture on land economics at the University of Padua.
Among the research scholars, a Connecticut college history instructor, Miss Irene Neu,
would go to the University of Catania, to carry on research on economic relations between
Sioily and the United States in the 19th century. A Cornell economist, Professor Alfred
Kahn, would conduct research on private and governmental capital formation in Italy since
1945, at the University of Home.
Professor John Black of Ohio State university would do research in experimental phone¬
tics at Catholic university of Milan.
But the vast majority of the Fulbrighters — 91 in all — were in the student category.
These were generally younger persons — many of them June graduates of American colleges
and universities. They had competed for — and won — more modest Fulbright scholarships
for a year of graduate-level work.
Their fields of learning ran. the gamut from classics to criminology; from sculpture to
physios; from geography to cinema tography. Some would do research for masters * theses or
Phi, D. dissertations. Others would engage in strictly professional! training. In the
latter group were 10 painters, 10 voice students and five pianists.
The group included two husband-wifo teams. Dante Germino, an M. A. Qraduage in political
science from Harvard, had received a Fulbright scholarship to study relations between Italian
state and party under fascism, at the University of Rome. His wife, Virginia, an M. A. in
history from Radcliffs college, had received her grant to study the oounter-reform and the
Italian baroque, at the same institution. Thomas and Jane Morgan, Ph. D. and M. A., respec¬
tively, from the University of Illinois, had received their scholarships to do special
research in physics at the University of Milan.
And there was a Catholic priest, Father Richard Schuler, from St. Thomas college of
St. Paul, Minn., who would study musicology at the University of Rome.
Inevitably, some of these students would ask, as some of their predecessors hadi Why
are we brought"together as a group for our orientation, given the wide range of our fields
of interest? why the decision to take all of us to Perugia, rather than dividing us into
small groups and assigning us to several different Italian university centers?
The Italian Fulbright program is administered by an Italo-American group known as the
American Commission for Cultural Exchange with Italy. Its executive secretary, Miss
Cipriana Soelba, explains commission thinking about orientation and Perugia*
